column2: Miami pioneer and railroad tycoon Henry Flagler used the property at U.S. 1 and Southwest 102 Street as a staging area during the construction of the Overseas Railroad to the Florida Keys.

the area's growth continued and the community began to evolve around one of the first tourist attractions established in the Miami vicinity – Parrot Jungle and Gardens.  Parrot Jungle was founded in 1936 by Franz and Louise Scherr on property located at Red Road and Southwest 111 Street and over the years has become a tourist attraction whose visitors included Sir Winston Churchill. The idea for Parrot Jungle began after Scherr
column3: who owned and operated a feed and supply store in Homestead
column5: became intrigued with the idea of building an attraction where birds would "fly free." To bring his vision to life
column6: he rented 20 acres (8.1 ha) of hammock land for an annual fee of $25 (equivalent to $460 in 2019). Parrot Jungle was built as a winding nature trail dug through the coral rock and hammock land
column7: indigenous to the area. All the natural plants were left undisturbed. The entrance was built on Red Road. The attraction opened on December 20
column9: to about 100 visitors. Each paid 25 cents admission to see and hear Scherr talk about his birds
column11: Parrot Jungle has attracted over a million visitors. On December 17
column13: the Village of Pinecrest purchased the Parrot Jungle with the aim of developing the site as Pinecrest Gardens. On March 8
column14: 2003 the Pinecrest Village Council dedicated Pinecrest Gardens and officially opened it to the public as the Village's newest municipal park. The attraction moved to a new waterfront location on Watson Island between Downtown Miami and Miami Beach. It was relaunched as Parrot Jungle Island.

column1: During the 1950s and 1960s the area flourished with the development and construction of ranch-style houses on 1 acre (0.40 ha) lots which laid the foundation for the community's rural and lushly landscaped residential character.

column2: Pinecrest and the surrounding South Miami-Dade area were severely devastated by the effects of Hurricane Andrew. Many of the homes and businesses in the area were destroyed. In the subsequent years
column3: the area was slowly rebuilt.Rapid growth and local issues during the 1990s inspired a movement led by residents Evelyn Greer Langlieb and Gary C. Matzner to incorporate the area. The Village of Pinecrest was officially incorporated on March 12
column4: 1996. Evelyn Greer was elected the first mayor and was succeeded
column6: by Matzner in 2004.  The founding Village Council
column12: together with Village Manager Peter G. Lombardi and Village Clerk Guido Inguanzo
column13: are credited with establishing well-regarded municipal services including police

column1: Miami-Dade Fire Rescue operates Station 49 Pinecrest.
